text:
As a freelance writer, I now find resumes frustrating. So I'm finally taking the advice of some brilliant here and creating a portfolio explaining what went into each piece (Did I work with editors? Did I come up with the topic? Why did I write this piece? etc.).

I've also started working on a sort of "backroom experience" document, explaining exactly what I did at my previous FT positions, what I learned in the process, sizes of the teams, proudest work; no buzzwords, just vibes. (I've finally decided to get on LinkedIn and just get over what stopped me so far: the absurdly high amount of marketing Gary Vee bros and faux deep stories on there. I want to include some of these "backroom" experience descriptions on my LinkedIn.)

*My question is*: Transparency is really important to me and at this point, I'm only looking to work with/write for ethical companies or orgs. So *I want to include a "Why I left" section for each position I've held since the most I've stayed in the same position has been a year and I realize that's far from ideal. Would the cons of writing such sections outweigh the pros?* At my first FT Writer job, at one point, I was asked to plagiarize other people's work just to produce daily content. Now, as I've written this whole thing, I realize maybe the cons outweigh the pros, but I'd like to know what Superpath-ers think.

_Obviously, I won't send this to people looking for a single article, but if an org/agency is looking for a long-term freelance collaborator, I'd like to offer a deeper view into my experience. (For example, I'd love to make use of my content marketing and psychology knowledge for opps beyond "just" writing.)_

elements.text:
As a freelance writer, I now find resumes frustrating. So I'm finally taking the advice of some brilliant here and creating a portfolio explaining what went into each piece (Did I work with editors? Did I come up with the topic? Why did I write this piece? etc.).

I've also started working on a sort of "backroom experience" document, explaining exactly what I did at my previous FT positions, what I learned in the process, sizes of the teams, proudest work; no buzzwords, just vibes. (I've finally decided to get on LinkedIn and just get over what stopped me so far: the absurdly high amount of marketing Gary Vee bros and faux deep stories on there. I want to include some of these "backroom" experience descriptions on my LinkedIn.)
My question is
: Transparency is really important to me and at this point, I'm only looking to work with/write for ethical companies or orgs. So

I want to include a "Why I left" section for each position I've held since the most I've stayed in the same position has been a year and I realize that's far from ideal. Would the cons of writing such sections outweigh the pros?

At my first FT Writer job, at one point, I was asked to plagiarize other people's work just to produce daily content. Now, as I've written this whole thing, I realize maybe the cons outweigh the pros, but I'd like to know what Superpath-ers think.

Obviously, I won't send this to people looking for a single article, but if an org/agency is looking for a long-term freelance collaborator, I'd like to offer a deeper view into my experience. (For example, I'd love to make use of my content marketing and psychology knowledge for opps beyond "just" writing.)

text:
Bugger that <@URL9Z88MR>! I say put it in. Integrity, honour, and transparency are some of one's greatest assets. If people can't deal with that, then it's their problem. As long as your reasons for moving on are legit and not nefarious or purely money driven, then you should be fine.
I was once asked why I left XYZ company, and I said it's because the system they promised/said was perfect for lead gen was actually a dogs breakfast, and the company I moved to, their system was much better. Hence, my historic clients were now much happier. I don't mince my words.

elements.text: Bugger that

! I say put it in. Integrity, honour, and transparency are some of one's greatest assets. If people can't deal with that, then it's their problem. As long as your reasons for moving on are legit and not nefarious or purely money driven, then you should be fine.
I was once asked why I left XYZ company, and I said it's because the system they promised/said was perfect for lead gen was actually a dogs breakfast, and the company I moved to, their system was much better. Hence, my historic clients were now much happier. I don't mince my words.

text: I think it can be really valuable to show potential clients what your values and principles are around your work but I think how you’ve described it here this kind of transparency could be seen as bad-mouthing your previous employers which could achieve the opposite of what you want - showing you have integrity. Maybe it’s more useful to dedicate a section of your portfolio to describing what kind of values are important to you and your writing. Then you could tackle the question of why your employment has been short at some companies in a more general sense: they didn’t always align with your values. And go on to describe the kind of companies you’d like to work with. This is still transparent without getting into the details of why they didn’t align with your values.

Then you could tackle the question of why your employment has been short at some companies in a more general sense: they didn’t always align with your values. And go on to describe the kind of companies you’d like to work with. This is still transparent without getting into the details of why they didn’t align with your values.

text:
I agree with <@U01GLCVCT89> - as a hiring manager I would skip over someone who publicly broadcasted  why they left previous roles. I urge you to think positively (“these are the things i care about”) rather than negatively (“company x had questionable ethics”).

You can accomplish the end goal here without making enemies.

elements.text: I agree with

- as a hiring manager I would skip over someone who publicly broadcasted  why they left previous roles. I urge you to think positively (“these are the things i care about”) rather than negatively (“company x had questionable ethics”).
You can accomplish the end goal here without making enemies.

text:
Thank you for sharing this, now I feel way more confident to include that section. For context, all my full-time positions have been in Albania, where laws to protect clients are nonexistent at worse and ambiguous at best and many companies take advantage of that. 

I left the other company I worked for for a similar reason to yours, so it's good to hear that the reason was well received (and that you found a place that delivered on what they promised which made your clients happier at the end of the day).

text: I'm super glad I could offer a bit of assistance/peace of mind Delfina. Yup, always be true to yourself and try to be the best human possible. :pray:

elements.text: I'm super glad I could offer a bit of assistance/peace of mind Delfina. Yup, always be true to yourself and try to be the best human possible.

text:
I consider myself a rational optimist, and I try to focus on what goes right rather than wrong, and while I understand that "best practices" say I shouldn't say anything negative about former employers, but instead, as you also mention, think positively of the experience, I wonder if that'd be just me self-gaslighting with some toxic positivity :smiling_face_with_tear:

I agree that publicly broadcasting it would be wrong.

But... As someone who is trying to live intentionally and mindfully, using a safe formula of what I think the hiring manager or the lead editor wants to hear feels a bit wrong. While I’ve never lied in interviews, I know for a fact that I’ve given part-truths more often than I’d like to admit, and I know that’s the case for a lot of my friends and colleagues too.

Worst part is, I believe this is exactly what’s asked of us during the hiring process.

So, I guess I wanted to contribute to a future of 100% honest conversations during hiring, even though from afar, it looks difficult to pull off and pretty chaotic. But thank you so much for the answer Sean, I love your work.

elements.text: I consider myself a rational optimist, and I try to focus on what goes right rather than wrong, and while I understand that "best practices" say I shouldn't say anything negative about former employers, but instead, as you also mention, think positively of the experience, I wonder if that'd be just me self-gaslighting with some toxic positivity

But... As someone who is trying to live intentionally and mindfully, using a safe formula of what I think the hiring manager or the lead editor wants to hear feels a bit wrong. While I’ve never lied in interviews, I know for a fact that I’ve given part-truths more often than I’d like to admit, and I know that’s the case for a lot of my friends and colleagues too.

Worst part is, I believe this is exactly what’s asked of us during the hiring process.

So, I guess I wanted to contribute to a future of 100% honest conversations during hiring, even though from afar, it looks difficult to pull off and pretty chaotic. But thank you so much for the answer Sean, I love your work.

text: Oh man, I completely agree with you about wanting the hiring process to facilitate more honesty. Coincidentally, something I’ve been thinking a lot about lately (not so strange since I work for a hiring software company :upside_down_face:) . I think if you embrace honesty you’ll attract clients that really suit you. I think I better understand your desire to be radically transparant in your portfolio. I totally think you can do this it’s just a matter of doing it in the right place/context and in the right way. Based on your thoughtful explanation here I think you’re totally capable of that.

text: I haven't worked with any before, but I used to follow Vooza videos back in the day. They did some content for some tech companies. My biggest concern/question would be how to make the video still feel like your brand. I remember with the Vooza vids, the brand was kinda lost in the humor and Vooza brand, because the other two were more dominant. I'd want to challenge a creative partner to create something outside their regular routine so it stands out more. Unless you featured them within something you already do, like Onboarding Joei, because then it would be heavily branded with a guest appearance by a personality.

text: In my current job search, I have also tried to be very transparent about my values and ask questions to figure out if a company's values align with mine. Perhaps if you look at the reasons you left previous companies, and then frame questions to get at those issues when you are interviewing. That has really helped me. If you want to go into more detail or have some specific examples, feel free to message me!

text:
My fave advice for blog intros is... don't bother!

If there's nothing natural to introduce the topic then maybe your blog doesn't need an intro.

I see so many forced intros and writers get hung up on stories that they forget some blog posts exist for the purpose of answering a question.

text: I had this problem for ages. The only solution was to write the body of the text first and come back to the intro and conclusion.

text: My favorite prompt is why do you _personally_ care about this topic. So many articles out there are written by people who are writing for clicks more than actual knowledge transfer. Intros that frame a personal investment really stand out.

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs

text:
Hi Delfina, I think it's a great idea to set values and boundaries for potential clients! Had an idea that might be helpful. Maybe split your portfolio in two:
• A 'what you get from me' section highlighting your work, so your client gets an idea of what you bring to the table.
• A 'what I expect from you' section, where you detail your values and how you expect your clients to live up to that. I think this could help set clear expectations, without going into previous employers and will not turn this into toxic positivity.

elements.text: Hi Delfina, I think it's a great idea to set values and boundaries for potential clients! Had an idea that might be helpful. Maybe split your portfolio in two:
A 'what you get from me' section highlighting your work, so your client gets an idea of what you bring to the table.

A 'what I expect from you' section, where you detail your values and how you expect your clients to live up to that. I think this could help set clear expectations, without going into previous employers and will not turn this into toxic positivity.
